Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the medical staff is celebrating the closure of the hospital's isolation rooms. The video and accompanying captions do not provide any specific details or context to confirm the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the closure of the isolation rooms is a positive development and implies that it signifies the end of the COVID-19 pandemic in the hospital. However, there is no information provided to support this assumption, and it may be premature or misleading.
Understate: The claim may understate the potential ongoing presence of COVID-19 cases in the hospital. The clarification comment from Dr. Khaled Al-Dahmashi mentions that there are still cases of COVID-19, indicating that the closure of the isolation rooms does not necessarily mean the complete eradication of the virus.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there are still cases of COVID-19 in the hospital, as mentioned in the clarification comment. This contradiction undermines the claim that the closure of the isolation rooms signifies the end of the pandemic in the hospital.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the celebration shown in the video. It is possible that the celebration is related to a different event or achievement unrelated to the closure of the isolation rooms. Without further information, it is difficult to determine the exact reason for the celebration.
